docs.lead_paragraph: Six years after making history by winning a United States Senate seat as first lady, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced this morning that she was taking the first formal step to seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, a journey that would break yet more political barriers in her extraordinary and controversial career.

headline.main: Clinton’s Announcement Makes Waves in ’08 Field

docs.snippet: Six years after making history by winning a United States Senate seat as first lady, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced this morning that she was taking the first formal step to seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, a journey...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Edward G. Rendell’s plan would not only extend health insurance coverage to the state’s 760,000 uninsured adults, but also cut billions of dollars in heath care costs.
docs.snippet: Gov. Edward G. Rendell’s plan would not only extend health insurance coverage to the state’s 760,000 uninsured adults, but also cut billions of dollars in heath care costs.

headline.main: The Marriage Ideal and Unwedded Bliss (3 Letters)
headline.print_headline: The Marriage Ideal And Unwedded Bliss

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Iraqi Government Drafts Law to Share Oil Revenue A cabinet-level committee has produced a draft law governing Iraq's oil fields that would distribute all revenue through the federal government and grant Baghdad wide powers in exploration, development and awarding contracts. A1 Senator Rebukes Iran Policy Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, the new chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, criticized the Bush administration's stance toward Iran, saying that efforts to portray it as a growing threat are reminiscent of rhetoric about Iraq before the American invasion. A1 Call for U.N. Activities Audit Ban Ki-moon, the new secretary general, called for outside examination of all United Nations activities after a report that the United Nations Development Program in North Korea was making unaccountable payments to the government and the staff there. A3 Armenian Editor Slain in Turkey A prominent newspaper editor, columnist and voice for Turkey's ethnic Armenians who was prosecuted for challenging the official Turkish version of the 1915 Armenian genocide, was shot dead in central Istanbul. A3 Palestinian Revenue Released Israel transferred $100 million in Palestinian tax revenue to the office of the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, and also suspended the establishment of a settlement in the West Bank. A5 Climate Panel to Give Warning The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is closing in on its strongest statement yet linking emissions from burning fossil fuels to rising global temperatures, scientists involved in the process said. A7 NATIONAL A8-9; 12 Ney Gets 2 1/2 Years In Lobbying Scandal Former Representative Bob Ney, the first member of Congress to plead guilty in the Jack Abramoff lobbying scandal, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, longer than had been requested by the Justice Department. A8 Court Revisits Campaign Law The Supreme Court stepped back into the debate over campaign finance regulation, announcing an expedited review of a ruling last month that substantially narrowed the application of a major provision of the McCain-Feingold law. A9 Governor Pushes Health Plan Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania is trying to rally support for his plan to extend health insurance coverage to the state's 760,000 uninsured adults, cut billions of dollars in heath care costs and ban smoking in restaurants, bars and workplaces. A9 Street Brawl Is Investigated Investigators are expected to travel to New Haven, Conn., to interview victims of a New Year's Day street fight in San Francisco that left several Yale students injured and the San Francisco police once again fending off criticism. A9 EDUCATION Loan Dispute Is Resolved The Bush administration reached a settlement with a student loan company that will allow the lender to keep $278 million in disputed subsidy payments that the inspector general of the federal Education Department had concluded were improper, the department announced. A8 Beliefs A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Nonprofits Develop Plans To Attract Wealthy Asians The divide between the growing number of wealthy Chinese-Americans and the newest, poorest Chinese immigrants in New York City has led nonprofit agencies to develop new methods of attracting wealthy Asian donors. Community-based nonprofits say that rich Chinese-Americans are more likely to donate to cultural institutions than to the poor. A1 21 Parishes to Close The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York issued a final list of 21 parishes that will close as part of a sweeping reorganization process that began several years ago and distressed thousands of parishioners who feared for the future of their churches. A1 5 Found Dead in House A family of five was found slain in their house in a working-class section of Dutchess County after firefighters responded to a blaze that gutted the home, the authorities said. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Dollar Remains Weak The dollar has lost ground against many of the world's major currencies, including the euro, the British pound and the Canadian dollar, but the nation's trade imbalance with the world has continued to rise. A1 Eli Lilly Drug Investigated Stepping up government investigations into Eli Lilly's marketing of its bestselling drug Zyprexa, state prosecutors in Illinois and Vermont have demanded that the company turn over information about the way it promoted the medication. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES C10 Denny Doherty A founding member of the band the Mamas and the Papas, he was 66. C10 EDITORIAL A10-11 Editorials: China's muscle flex in space; reform, finally, in the Senate; a product of the U.N. system; Verlyn Klinkenborg on the prefix ''post-.'' Columns: Maureen Dowd, Stacy Schiff. Bridge B17 Crossword B15 TV Listings B18 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Elusive Altar'' (column, Jan. 18):

headline.main: The Marriage Ideal And Unwedded Bliss

docs.abstract: Three letters respond to David Brooks's Jan 18 Op-Ed contending that marriage should be seen as social machine that can be useful for achieving practical ends; Brenda A Becker says successful marriages start out as state of sacred bliss; Nicky Grist disputes Brooks's assertion that being unmarried is being trapped in no man's land between solitude and marriage; Robert M Charde says Brooks recommends that we strengthen marriage by encouraging people to value it less and engage in it more, but he does not discuss 'except gay people' clause
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''The Elusive Altar'' (column, Jan. 18):

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, drew a battle line with President Bush on Iran today during a joint appearance with Representative Nancy Pelosi, the Democrats' leader in the House. As part of the Democrats' runup to Mr. Bush's address to the nation on Tuesday night, Mr. Reid reminded the commander in chief that his power does have limits when it comes to military engagement.

headline.main: Reid Stands Between Bush and Iran

docs.abstract: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, drew a battle line with President Bush on Iran.
docs.snippet: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, drew a battle line with President Bush on Iran.

docs.lead_paragraph: The largest insurer in Europe announced that it would buy out the minority shareholders of its French subsidiary AGF for $12.6 billion.

headline.main: To Simplify, Allianz Will Acquire All of French Unit
headline.print_headline: To Simplify, Allianz Will Acquire All of French Unit

docs.snippet: The largest insurer in Europe announced that it would buy out the minority shareholders of its French subsidiary AGF for $12.6 billion.
